title: The most important ancient historian is Polybius (c. 200–c.118 BCE), who covered much the same period as this book of mine, but in forty books. title: Fragments of other historians and the work even of more literary authors cast rare but precious extra light.. But the most important not-strictly-historical source is Plutarch, the essayist and biographer of the late first and early second centuries CE. His Lives include a number of relevant biographies: Philopoemen and Flamininus (paired together as parallel Lives), Cato the Elder, Pyrrhus, Aemilius Paullus, and Aratus. Cato the Elder and Aemilius Paullus were included in my Plutarch: Roman Lives
while the rest will be included in my Plutarch: Hellenistic Lives
